title: Git Fundamentals
description: Master essential Git commands, workflows, and version control concepts.

cards.front: What command initializes a new Git repository?
cards.back: git init - Creates a new .git directory in the current folder, initializing version control.

cards.front: How do you stage all changes for commit?
cards.back: git add . or git add -A - Stages all modified and new files in the working directory.

cards.front: What's the difference between 'git pull' and 'git fetch'?
cards.back: git fetch downloads changes without merging them, while git pull downloads AND merges changes into the current branch.

cards.front: How do you create a new branch?
cards.back: git branch <branch-name> or git checkout -b <branch-name> (creates and switches to the new branch).

cards.front: What command shows the commit history?
cards.back: git log - Shows commit history with hash, author, date, and message. Use git log --oneline for compact view.

cards.front: How do you undo the last commit (keep changes)?
cards.back: git reset --soft HEAD~1 - Moves HEAD back one commit but keeps changes staged.
Specifies intentionally untracked files that Git should ignore (build artifacts, IDE files, secrets, etc.).

cards.front: How do you merge a branch into the current branch?
cards.back: git merge <branch-name> - Combines the specified branch's history into the current branch.
git diff - Shows unstaged changes. Use git diff --staged to see staged changes.

cards.front: How do you rename a branch?
cards.back: git branch -m <old-name> <new-name> or git branch -m <new-name> (if on the branch to rename).

cards.front: What's the difference between 'git merge' and 'git rebase'?
cards.back: merge creates a merge commit and preserves history; rebase replays commits on top of another branch, creating linear history.

cards.front: How do you delete a remote branch?
cards.back: git push origin --delete <branch-name> or git push origin :<branch-name>
git commit -m 'message' - Creates a commit with staged changes. Use -a flag to auto-stage modified files.

cards.front: How do you stash uncommitted changes?
cards.back: git stash - Saves changes temporarily. Use git stash pop to restore them later.
When target branch hasn't diverged, Git simply moves the branch pointer forward without creating a merge commit.

cards.front: How do you cherry-pick a commit?
cards.back: git cherry-pick <commit-hash> - Applies changes from a specific commit to the current branch.

cards.front: What command shows current branch and status?
cards.back: git status - Shows current branch, staged/unstaged changes, and untracked files.

cards.front: How do you create an annotated tag?
cards.back: git tag -a v1.0 -m 'message' - Creates a tag with metadata (author, date, message). Push with git push --tags.
